title: About Me
text:
I am a Master of Business Analytics student at Monash University, originally from New Delhi, India. My academic and professional journey reflects a strong interest in how data-driven thinking can shape smarter, evidence-based decisions.
Before beginning my master‚Äôs, I worked in the investment industry at Aditya Birla Sun Life AMC, where I learned how data and analytics underpin financial strategy, portfolio management, and client insights. This experience built my appreciation for how numbers tell meaningful stories when translated effectively.
I‚Äôm particularly passionate about transforming complex data into clear, actionable narratives through analytics and visualisation. My studies have strengthened my foundation in statistics, programming, and communication, helping me explore the full process ‚Äî from data wrangling to interpretation and presentation.
Beyond university, I enjoy playing basketball, going to the gym, baking, and travelling. These interests keep me balanced and curious ‚Äî qualities I believe also drive thoughtful analysis and problem-solving.



Data & Code: R (tidyverse, ggplot2, Quarto), Python (pandas), Git/GitHub

Analysis: data visualisation, exploratory data analysis (EDA), model evaluation, and reproducible pipelines

Communication: concise analytical writing, clear figure design, and stakeholder-focused reporting





Developing high-quality, publication-ready reports using R and Quarto with strong documentation and cross-referencing

Enhancing my ability to translate analytical findings into strategic business insights

Building collaborative and reproducible workflows that promote transparency and team efficiency




This site showcases selected coursework and mini-projects from my analytics journey at Monash University. It‚Äôs an evolving space where I continue to refine my writing, visualisation style, and coding practices as I grow as an analyst.

title: Delta Variant and the Limits of Quarantine Effectiveness
text:
The Delta variant of SARS-CoV-2 posed a major challenge to countries that relied on strict border quarantine to prevent outbreaks. Even with high vaccination rates, the variant‚Äôs higher transmissibility raised the question: could existing quarantine systems still contain imported infections?
This analysis revisits the study by Zachreson et al.¬†(2022), which modelled the interaction between vaccine efficacy, transmission rates, and infection-control measures within quarantine systems similar to those used in Australia and New Zealand.


Quarantine breaches were rare before Delta, but the variant‚Äôs basic reproduction number (ùëÖ‚ÇÄ ‚âà 6‚Äì8) made containment far more difficult.
The key question addressed was:
To what extent can vaccination and infection control offset the increased transmissibility of Delta in border-quarantine environments?



The authors used simulation modelling combining two components:

a quarantine model for 100 travellers and 20 workers over a 14-day period with PCR testing and case isolation, and

a branching-process model to estimate community-outbreak probabilities from breach events.

Scenarios varied vaccine efficacy (0‚Äì90 %), transmissibility (ùëÖ‚ÇÄ = 3‚Äì10), and infection-control strength, allowing the study to test which combinations could maintain pre-Delta safety levels.











Figure¬†1: Heatmap of R‚ÇÄ and vaccine efficacy showing outbreak risk.





Figure¬†1 illustrates how higher transmissibility sharply increased outbreak risk, even at high vaccine efficacy.


Code
# Created a small data frame
delta_summary <- data.frame(
  Scenario = c("Base Case", "High Efficacy", "Weak Control", "Very High R‚ÇÄ"),
  `Vaccine Efficacy (%)` = c(70, 90, 70, 80),
  `R‚ÇÄ` = c(6, 6, 6, 8),
  `Infection Control` = c("Strong", "Strong", "Weak", "Strong"),
  `Relative Outbreak Risk` = c("Moderate", "Low", "High", "High"))

# Table
kable(
  delta_summary,
  caption = "Summary of simulated scenarios showing combined effects of vaccine efficacy, transmissibility, and infection control on outbreak risk.",
  align = "lcccl")



Summary of simulated scenarios showing combined effects of vaccine efficacy, transmissibility, and infection control on outbreak risk.









Scenario
Vaccine.Efficacy‚Ä¶.
R.
Infection.Control
Relative.Outbreak.Risk




Base Case
70
6
Strong
Moderate


High Efficacy
90
6
Strong

70
6

80
8
Strong
High









Vaccination alone is insufficient. At ùëÖ‚ÇÄ ‚â• 6, vaccine efficacy above 70‚Äì80% is required just to maintain pre-Delta safety.

Infection control remains critical. Weak quarantine protocols amplified breach risk up to 100√ó under low-efficacy conditions.

Combined defences work best. High efficacy plus strong testing and isolation delayed the median time to outbreak from ‚âà 15 days to > 1000 days.




The study underscores that vaccination programs and strict quarantine measures must operate together.
Relying solely on vaccine protection against highly transmissible variants risks repeated breaches.
For health agencies, this means maintaining multi-layered defence systems ‚Äî vaccination, testing, ventilation, and rapid isolation ‚Äî to reduce outbreak probability and manage imported risk effectively.

title: Delta Variant and the Limits of Quarantine Effectiveness
text:
Vaccination alone is insufficient. At ùëÖ‚ÇÄ ‚â• 6, vaccine efficacy above 70‚Äì80% is required just to maintain pre-Delta safety.

title: Delta Variant and the Limits of Quarantine Effectiveness

The study underscores that vaccination programs and strict quarantine measures must operate together.
Relying solely on vaccine protection against highly transmissible variants risks repeated breaches.

title: Delta Variant and the Limits of Quarantine Effectiveness
text:
Delta reshaped the risk landscape for border management.
The modelling shows that even strong vaccination coverage cannot fully offset the variant‚Äôs transmissibility without robust infection control.
For future preparedness, quarantine should be treated as a recurring necessity, not a temporary measure, ensuring that systems remain adaptable to emerging variants.

title: Delta Variant and the Limits of Quarantine Effectiveness
text:
Zachreson, C., Shearer, F. M., Price, D. J., Lydeamore, M. J., McVernon, J., McCaw, J. M., & Geard, N. (2022).
COVID-19 in low-tolerance border quarantine systems: Impact of the Delta variant of SARS-CoV-2.
Science Advances, 8(14), eabm3624. https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.abm3624
Table @ref(tab:delta_summary) summarises the main scenario outcomes.
